content: Know that you are not alone. If you have been diagnosed with bipolar, you may feel scared and alone. However, many people deal with mood disorders every day. Over 22 million people in America have been diagnosed with mood disorders. There are many people to reach out to who deal with the disorder, and there are many resources available to you. [2] Many people are treated for bipolar every day and successfully live with this condition. You are not the only person dealing with the disorder or the only person being treated. You might also try looking into notable people who have had bipolar disorder to see that you can still achieve your dreams with this disorder. The list of notable people who have struggled with bipolar disorder includes Carrie Fisher, Tim Burton, Ted Turner, Buzz Aldrin, and Ludwig van Beethoven to name a few. [3] Realize that you are not crazy. When you get diagnosed with bipolar, numerous thoughts may be running through your head. You may be thinking about ways bipolar disorder has been viewed in the media or about misconceptions you have. You may think you are crazy or weak. This is not true. Bipolar disorder is an imbalance of chemicals in your brain, which is out of your control. [4] Having bipolar disorder does not mean you are less of a person or that you are not “normal.” You just have a chemical issue with your brain that can be managed through treatment. Embrace your emotions. If you feel emotional after your diagnosis, don’t suppress those emotions. Instead, let yourself feel those emotions. You may be scared, ashamed, angry, or sad. You may feel emotional pain. You may not understand why this happened to you or be resistant to accepting that your life will change with treatment. Let yourself go through these emotions. [5] Trying to suppress emotions can cause more problems. When you let yourself feel and experience the emotions, even if they are negative, then you work through them, let them out, and move on. If you need to cry or scream, do it. The sooner you let go of those emotions, the closer you will be to accepting your diagnosis. You can also try talking with a trusted friend or family member or writing about your emotions. Realize your diagnosis does not define you. You are not the bipolar disorder. Bipolar disorder is only a brain imbalance. You are you. You did not cause the bipolar, it is not your fault, and you are not a bad person. Bipolar disorder is just something you have to live with, like diabetes, asthma, thyroid issues, or arthritis. [6] You have probably had the disorder since birth and inherited it from a family member. Bipolar disorder is just one aspect of your life. If you put it into perspective, that it is one piece just like your favorite color, your favorite food, your favorite activities, and your career, it feels less overwhelming. Be patient. For some people, acceptance of their bipolar diagnosis may take years. Some people deny that they have bipolar at all, while others see improvements and stop accepting that they have it. Be patient as your work towards acceptance and as you and your treatment team find what works best for you. Remind yourself that though you have this mental illness, acknowledge and treatment is the way to help you stay healthy. [7] Often a diagnosis of bipolar II is more difficult to accept than bipolar I because the symptoms are milder. Accept that your loved one is bipolar. It can be difficult to hear that your loved one has bipolar disorder. You may think that everything will change, including your relationship with them. However, remember that your loved one is still the same person they always have been. Your loved one now is able to get treatment for their symptoms, manage their disorder, and live a fuller life. Learn about bipolar disorder. One of the first things you should do after you get diagnosed with bipolar is to learn as much about bipolar as you can. This includes the symptoms, especially the symptoms of a manic episode. You should also learn about treatment options so you can make an informed decision about how to treat the disorder. You may have misconceptions about bipolar because of your exposure to incorrect information in the past. Start researching bipolar as if you have never heard of the condition before. Ask your doctor for resources. You can also find books on the subject, or look at reputable websites online. The Depression and Bipolar Support Alliance and National Alliance on Mental Illness are good resources to start with. Get a second opinion. If you are unsure about your bipolar diagnosis, get a second opinion. Make an appointment to see a different psychiatrist, or search for an expert in bipolar disorders. Getting a second opinion never hurts, especially since mental illnesses can be difficult to diagnose. If you have only seen your general physician but not a mental health expert, go see a psychiatrist, psychologist, therapist, or other mental health professional before you start treatment. Seek support. Learning to accept your bipolar diagnosis and getting treatment may be difficult. You shouldn’t try to do it alone. Reach out to trusted family and friends for help. Tell them about your diagnosis, along with your fears or concerns. Ask them to be there for you if you need them. Be aware that some people's opinions of you might change due to their lack of knowledge about the condition. This type of reaction would be entirely unwarranted. However, you might consider this as you are deciding who to tell. [8] Connect with others who are bipolar. Millions of people around the world have bipolar disorder or other mood disorders. You may want to reach out and talk to others who are dealing with bipolar. These people are going through the same things you are, so they can help provide support and understand what you are feeling. You may consider going to a bipolar disorder support group. These meetings will give you a safe space to talk about your feelings, ask questions, and discuss struggles and successes with others. You may talk to them about how they learned to accept the diagnosis. You may be able to find a support group online, such as by checking the NAMI website. [9] Reach out online to others with bipolar. Many bipolar organizations have online communities where you can talk to people from around the world. Research with your loved one. If your loved one has bipolar, do your own research. This can help you understand the symptoms, treatment, and prognosis for your loved one. Visit support groups with them, offer to go to the doctor, or talk to your loved one about their condition. It may be helpful for you to learn about bipolar symptoms treatment. Think about what symptoms your loved one has demonstrated before. Learn how treatment will help those symptoms and give your loved one a more balanced life. Remind yourself why treatment is important. Deciding to get treatment may feel like giving up or admitting defeat. That is an unhealthy way of thinking about your treatment. Bipolar treatment is very effective and can make your life better. Untreated bipolar is dangerous and can lead to destructive behavior. [10] Be honest with yourself about your bipolar, your symptoms, and your actions. You may be productive in manic phases, but make a list of the negatives. Have you had relationship problems? Participated in unsafe or risky behaviors? Gotten into debt? Left untreated, bipolar can have a negative effect on your life. Commit to treatment. One way to fully accept your diagnosis is to commit yourself to following your treatment. This means you go to your doctor’s appointments, you take your medication, and you make the appropriate lifestyle changes. [11] It is important to continue your treatment even if you start to feel better. Only going halfway with your treatment is telling yourself you don’t need help because there’s nothing wrong with you. Choose a bipolar specialist. When you are searching for a doctor to treat your bipolar, you should find one who specializes in bipolar disorder. Not all psychiatrists, psychologists, and therapists have experience treating the same thing. When you go to the doctor, ask them about their experience treating bipolar disorder. [12] When you are searching for psychiatrists online or through your insurance company, you can usually find a list of the psychiatrist’s specializations in the info section. If you are unsure, contact the psychiatrist’s office to find out. Ask your general practitioner for a referral for a good clinic. You may have a treatment team that includes a doctor or psychiatrist who handles your medication and a therapist, psychologist, or licensed social worker who oversees your therapy. Take medication. Treatment for bipolar generally combines medication with therapy. Not everyone responds to medication the same way, so you may try a few different types of medications before choosing the right one for you. Discuss your medication options with your doctor. [13] The medications prescribed for bipolar disorder are mood stabilizers, atypical antipsychotics, and antidepressants. The aim of medication is to stabilize your moods. [14] Go to therapy. Psychotherapy is a common treatment for bipolar disorder. Often, you will receive cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). In cognitive behavioral therapy, you work on replacing negative thought patterns with healthier ones. For bipolar, you and your therapist work on identifying and avoiding triggers, problem solving skills, and managing your symptoms. [15] Another common therapy for bipolar is interpersonal and social rhythm therapy. Interpersonal therapy works on helping you improve your relationships. Improving relationships can help reduce stress, which is a big trigger for bipolar. Social rhythm therapy works on getting your daily routine normalized by helping you adopt better sleeping, eating, and exercising schedules. Manage your symptoms. Certain lifestyle changes can help you manage your bipolar disorder. You should get on a regular sleep schedule. Getting enough rest helps keep your mood level. Regular exercising also helps with your symptoms. Exercise is a natural mood booster and can help you feel better. [16] Work on stress relieving techniques. This may include yoga, Tai Chi, exercise, meditation , or deep breathing exercises . Refrain from using drugs or alcohol. Both of these things can exacerbate mood swings and trigger relapses.

<div class="section sticky hasad" id="intro">
<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Accept-a-Bipolar-Disorder-Diagnosis">How to Accept a Bipolar Disorder Diagnosis</a></h1>
<div class="ss_check" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="expert_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		Paul Chernyak, LPC</a>
</div>
<p class="vertical_toc" id="method_toc">
<span class="header_toc">Explore this Article</span>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Coming_to_Terms_with_the_Diagnosis_sub" id="">Coming to Terms with the Diagnosis</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Seeking_Information_About_the_Disorder_sub" id="">Seeking Information About the Disorder</a>
<a class="toc_method" href="#Creating_a_Treatment_Plan_sub" id="">Creating a Treatment Plan</a>
<a class="" href="#Questions_and_Answers_sub" id="qa_toc">Ask a Question</a>

<a class="toc_ref" href="#references" id="">References</a>
</p>
<div hidden="" id="sp_icon_hover">
<div id="sp_icon_body">
		This article was co-authored by <a href="/Special:ArticleReviewers?name=paulchernyak%2Clpc#paulchernyak%2Clpc">Paul Chernyak, LPC</a>. Paul Chernyak is a Licensed Professional Counselor in Chicago. He graduated from the American School of Professional Psychology in 2011.<br/><br/>There are <a href="#references">16 references</a> cited in this article, which can be found at the bottom of the page.
		
	</div>
</div>
<p>Hearing that you have bipolar disorder can be a difficult moment. You may not believe your doctor or think there is nothing wrong with you. Around two-thirds of people who are diagnosed with bipolar have trouble accepting the diagnosis<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>. Though it may take a long time, through educating yourself, seeking support, and committing to a treatment plan, you can learn to accept your diagnosis.</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Coming_to_Terms_with_the_Diagnosis_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Coming_to_Terms_with_the_Diagnosis">Coming to Terms with the Diagnosis</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Convince Yourself That You're Happy Being Alone Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-16.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-16.jpg" height="546" id="img_835eee3da4" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_835eee3da4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Convince Yourself That You're Happy Being Alone Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5c/Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-16.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Know that you are not alone.</b> If you have been diagnosed with bipolar, you may feel scared and alone. However, many people deal with mood disorders every day. Over 22 million people in America have been diagnosed with mood disorders. There are many people to reach out to who deal with the disorder, and there are many resources available to you.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Many people are treated for bipolar every day and successfully live with this condition. You are not the only person dealing with the disorder or the only person being treated.</li>
<li>You might also try looking into notable people who have had bipolar disorder to see that you can still achieve your dreams with this disorder. The list of notable people who have struggled with bipolar disorder includes Carrie Fisher, Tim Burton, Ted Turner, Buzz Aldrin, and Ludwig van Beethoven to name a few.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Convince Yourself That You're Happy Being Alone Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6d/Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_75e6ae44f1" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_75e6ae44f1')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Convince Yourself That You're Happy Being Alone Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6d/Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Convince-Yourself-That-You%27re-Happy-Being-Alone-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Realize that you are not crazy.</b> When you get diagnosed with bipolar, numerous thoughts may be running through your head. You may be thinking about ways bipolar disorder has been viewed in the media or about misconceptions you have. You may think you are crazy or weak. This is not true. Bipolar disorder is an imbalance of chemicals in your brain, which is out of your control.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Having bipolar disorder does not mean you are less of a person or that you are not “normal.” You just have a chemical issue with your brain that can be managed through treatment.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Yourself-from-Crying-Step-13-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Stop-Yourself-from-Crying-Step-13-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Yourself from Crying Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Stop-Yourself-from-Crying-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Stop-Yourself-from-Crying-Step-13-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_0d97900513" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0d97900513')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Yourself from Crying Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/db/Stop-Yourself-from-Crying-Step-13-Version-3.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Stop-Yourself-from-Crying-Step-13-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Embrace your emotions.</b> If you feel emotional after your diagnosis, don’t suppress those emotions. Instead, let yourself feel those emotions. You may be scared, ashamed, angry, or sad. You may feel emotional pain. You may not understand why this happened to you or be resistant to accepting that your life will change with treatment. Let yourself go through these emotions.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Trying to suppress emotions can cause more problems. When you let yourself feel and experience the emotions, even if they are negative, then you work through them, let them out, and move on.</li>
<li>If you need to cry or scream, do it. The sooner you let go of those emotions, the closer you will be to accepting your diagnosis. You can also try talking with a trusted friend or family member or writing about your emotions.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Stop-Crying-Step-18-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Stop-Crying-Step-18-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Stop Crying Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Stop-Crying-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Stop-Crying-Step-18-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_c0be7b7b48" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c0be7b7b48')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Stop Crying Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c8/Stop-Crying-Step-18-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Stop-Crying-Step-18-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Realize your diagnosis does not define you.</b> You are not the bipolar disorder. Bipolar disorder is only a brain imbalance. You are you. You did not cause the bipolar, it is not your fault, and you are not a bad person. Bipolar disorder is just something you have to live with, like diabetes, asthma, thyroid issues, or arthritis.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup> You have probably had the disorder since birth and inherited it from a family member.

<ul>
<li>Bipolar disorder is just one aspect of your life. If you put it into perspective, that it is one piece just like your favorite color, your favorite food, your favorite activities, and your career, it feels less overwhelming.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-11-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-11-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Convince Yourself Not to Commit Suicide Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_39d20b9566" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_39d20b9566')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Convince Yourself Not to Commit Suicide Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Be patient.</b> For some people, acceptance of their bipolar diagnosis may take years. Some people deny that they have bipolar at all, while others see improvements and stop accepting that they have it. Be patient as your work towards acceptance and as you and your treatment team find what works best for you. Remind yourself that though you have this mental illness, acknowledge and treatment is the way to help you stay healthy.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Often a diagnosis of bipolar II is more difficult to accept than bipolar I because the symptoms are milder.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-2-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-2-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Convince Yourself Not to Commit Suicide Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_75eb176b6a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_75eb176b6a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Convince Yourself Not to Commit Suicide Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ca/Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Convince-Yourself-Not-to-Commit-Suicide-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Accept that your loved one is bipolar.</b> It can be difficult to hear that your loved one has bipolar disorder. You may think that everything will change, including your relationship with them. However, remember that your loved one is still the same person they always have been.

<ul>
<li>Your loved one now is able to get treatment for their symptoms, manage their disorder, and live a fuller life.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Seeking_Information_About_the_Disorder_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Seeking_Information_About_the_Disorder">Seeking Information About the Disorder</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-Proud-to-Be-Black-Step-5-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Be-Proud-to-Be-Black-Step-5-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be Proud to Be Black Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/98/Be-Proud-to-Be-Black-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Be-Proud-to-Be-Black-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_e052e77524" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e052e77524')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be Proud to Be Black Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/98/Be-Proud-to-Be-Black-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Be-Proud-to-Be-Black-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Learn about bipolar disorder.</b> One of the first things you should do after you get diagnosed with bipolar is to learn as much about bipolar as you can. This includes the symptoms, especially the symptoms of a manic episode. You should also learn about treatment options so you can make an informed decision about how to treat the disorder.

<ul>
<li>You may have misconceptions about bipolar because of your exposure to incorrect information in the past. Start researching bipolar as if you have never heard of the condition before.</li>
<li>Ask your doctor for resources. You can also find books on the subject, or look at reputable websites online. The <a class="external text" href="http://www.dbsalliance.org/site/PageServer?pagename=education_bipolar" rel="nofollow">Depression and Bipolar Support Alliance</a> and <a class="external text" href="http://www.nami.org/Learn-More/Mental-Health-Conditions/Bipolar-Disorder" rel="nofollow">National Alliance on Mental Illness</a> are good resources to start with.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-17-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-17-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Good About Yourself Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-17-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_5d41ec8de6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5d41ec8de6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Good About Yourself Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/97/Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-17-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-17-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get a second opinion.</b> If you are unsure about your bipolar diagnosis, get a second opinion. Make an appointment to see a different psychiatrist, or search for an expert in bipolar disorders. Getting a second opinion never hurts, especially since mental illnesses can be difficult to diagnose.

<ul>
<li>If you have only seen your general physician but not a mental health expert, go see a psychiatrist, psychologist, therapist, or other mental health professional before you start treatment.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Feel Good About Yourself Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_3b4cda22b8" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3b4cda22b8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Feel Good About Yourself Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/35/Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Feel-Good-About-Yourself-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Seek support.</b> Learning to accept your bipolar diagnosis and getting treatment may be difficult. You shouldn’t try to do it alone. Reach out to trusted family and friends for help. Tell them about your diagnosis, along with your fears or concerns. Ask them to be there for you if you need them.

<ul>
<li>Be aware that some people's opinions of you might change due to their lack of knowledge about the condition. This type of reaction would be entirely unwarranted. However, you might consider this as you are deciding who to tell.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Conduct-Research-Step-1Bullet1.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Conduct-Research-Step-1Bullet1.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Conduct Research Step 1Bullet1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/38/Conduct-Research-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Conduct-Research-Step-1Bullet1.jpg" height="546" id="img_d8126d6481" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d8126d6481')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Conduct Research Step 1Bullet1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/38/Conduct-Research-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Conduct-Research-Step-1Bullet1.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Connect with others who are bipolar.</b> Millions of people around the world have bipolar disorder or other mood disorders. You may want to reach out and talk to others who are dealing with bipolar. These people are going through the same things you are, so they can help provide support and understand what you are feeling.

<ul>
<li>You may consider going to a bipolar disorder support group. These meetings will give you a safe space to talk about your feelings, ask questions, and discuss struggles and successes with others. You may talk to them about how they learned to accept the diagnosis. You may be able to find a support group online, such as by checking the NAMI website.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Reach out online to others with bipolar. Many bipolar organizations have online communities where you can talk to people from around the world.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Conduct-Research-Step-6.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Conduct-Research-Step-6.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Conduct Research Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Conduct-Research-Step-6.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Conduct-Research-Step-6.jpg" height="546" id="img_570b78e870" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_570b78e870')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Conduct Research Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a5/Conduct-Research-Step-6.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Conduct-Research-Step-6.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Research with your loved one.</b> If your loved one has bipolar, do your own research. This can help you understand the symptoms, treatment, and prognosis for your loved one. Visit support groups with them, offer to go to the doctor, or talk to your loved one about their condition.

<ul>
<li>It may be helpful for you to learn about bipolar symptoms treatment. Think about what symptoms your loved one has demonstrated before. Learn how treatment will help those symptoms and give your loved one a more balanced life.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Creating_a_Treatment_Plan_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Creating_a_Treatment_Plan">Creating a Treatment Plan</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Be-Single-and-Happy-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Be-Single-and-Happy-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Be Single and Happy Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Be-Single-and-Happy-Step-11.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Be-Single-and-Happy-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_f8c2a07e23" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f8c2a07e23')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Be Single and Happy Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Be-Single-and-Happy-Step-11.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Be-Single-and-Happy-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Remind yourself why treatment is important.</b> Deciding to get treatment may feel like giving up or admitting defeat. That is an unhealthy way of thinking about your treatment. Bipolar treatment is very effective and can make your life better. Untreated bipolar is dangerous and can lead to destructive behavior.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Be honest with yourself about your bipolar, your symptoms, and your actions. You may be productive in manic phases, but make a list of the negatives. Have you had relationship problems? Participated in unsafe or risky behaviors? Gotten into debt? Left untreated, bipolar can have a negative effect on your life.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cleanse-the-Lymph-System-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Cleanse-the-Lymph-System-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cleanse the Lymph System Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Cleanse-the-Lymph-System-Step-15.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Cleanse-the-Lymph-System-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_4452789b8a" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4452789b8a')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cleanse the Lymph System Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/ce/Cleanse-the-Lymph-System-Step-15.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Cleanse-the-Lymph-System-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Commit to treatment.</b> One way to fully accept your diagnosis is to commit yourself to following your treatment. This means you go to your doctor’s appointments, you take your medication, and you make the appropriate lifestyle changes.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup> It is important to continue your treatment even if you start to feel better.

<ul>
<li>Only going halfway with your treatment is telling yourself you don’t need help because there’s nothing wrong with you.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-12-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-12-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cope when No One Cares About You Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_a732ae5942" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a732ae5942')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cope when No One Cares About You Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0b/Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-12-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-12-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose a bipolar specialist.</b> When you are searching for a doctor to treat your bipolar, you should find one who specializes in bipolar disorder. Not all psychiatrists, psychologists, and therapists have experience treating the same thing. When you go to the doctor, ask them about their experience treating bipolar disorder.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>When you are searching for psychiatrists online or through your insurance company, you can usually find a list of the psychiatrist’s specializations in the info section. If you are unsure, contact the psychiatrist’s office to find out.</li>
<li>Ask your general practitioner for a referral for a good clinic.</li>
<li>You may have a treatment team that includes a doctor or psychiatrist who handles your medication and a therapist, psychologist, or licensed social worker who oversees your therapy.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-2-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-2-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Treat Upper Back Pain Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_bf7cea3e59" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_bf7cea3e59')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Treat Upper Back Pain Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2d/Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Treat-Upper-Back-Pain-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take medication.</b> Treatment for bipolar generally combines medication with therapy. Not everyone responds to medication the same way, so you may try a few different types of medications before choosing the right one for you. Discuss your medication options with your doctor.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>The medications prescribed for bipolar disorder are mood stabilizers, atypical antipsychotics, and antidepressants.</li>
<li>The aim of medication is to stabilize your moods.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-13-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-13-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cope when No One Cares About You Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-13-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_271678e922" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_271678e922')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cope when No One Cares About You Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/33/Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-13-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-13-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Go to therapy.</b> Psychotherapy is a common treatment for bipolar disorder. Often, you will receive cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). In cognitive behavioral therapy, you work on replacing negative thought patterns with healthier ones. For bipolar, you and your therapist work on identifying and avoiding triggers, problem solving skills, and managing your symptoms.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Another common therapy for bipolar is interpersonal and social rhythm therapy. Interpersonal therapy works on helping you improve your relationships. Improving relationships can help reduce stress, which is a big trigger for bipolar. Social rhythm therapy works on getting your daily routine normalized by helping you adopt better sleeping, eating, and exercising schedules.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-11-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=7854554" href="#/Image:Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-11-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Cope when No One Cares About You Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_392c6d33e3" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_392c6d33e3')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Cope when No One Cares About You Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/34/Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-11-Version-2.jpg/aid7854554-v4-728px-Cope-when-No-One-Cares-About-You-Step-11-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Manage your symptoms.</b> Certain lifestyle changes can help you manage your bipolar disorder. You should get on a regular sleep schedule. Getting enough rest helps keep your mood level. Regular exercising also helps with your symptoms. Exercise is a natural mood booster and can help you feel better.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Work on stress relieving techniques. This may include yoga, Tai Chi, exercise, <a href="/Meditate" title="Meditate">meditation</a>, or <a href="/Breathe-Deeply" title="Breathe Deeply">deep breathing exercises</a>.</li>
<li>Refrain from using drugs or alcohol. Both of these things can exacerbate mood swings and trigger relapses.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

{{#topCats.0}}

title: How to Accept a Bipolar Disorder Diagnosis
content_html:
Know that you are not alone. If you have been diagnosed with bipolar, you may feel scared and alone. However, many people deal with mood disorders every day. Over 22 million people in America have been diagnosed with mood disorders. There are many people to reach out to who deal with the disorder, and there are many resources available to you.[2]
  • Many people are treated for bipolar every day and successfully live with this condition. You are not the only person dealing with the disorder or the only person being treated.
  • You might also try looking into notable people who have had bipolar disorder to see that you can still achieve your dreams with this disorder. The list of notable people who have struggled with bipolar disorder includes Carrie Fisher, Tim Burton, Ted Turner, Buzz Aldrin, and Ludwig van Beethoven to name a few.[3]
Realize that you are not crazy. When you get diagnosed with bipolar, numerous thoughts may be running through your head. You may be thinking about ways bipolar disorder has been viewed in the media or about misconceptions you have. You may think you are crazy or weak. This is not true. Bipolar disorder is an imbalance of chemicals in your brain, which is out of your control.[4]
  • Having bipolar disorder does not mean you are less of a person or that you are not “normal.” You just have a chemical issue with your brain that can be managed through treatment.
Embrace your emotions. If you feel emotional after your diagnosis, don’t suppress those emotions. Instead, let yourself feel those emotions. You may be scared, ashamed, angry, or sad. You may feel emotional pain. You may not understand why this happened to you or be resistant to accepting that your life will change with treatment. Let yourself go through these emotions.[5]
  • Trying to suppress emotions can cause more problems. When you let yourself feel and experience the emotions, even if they are negative, then you work through them, let them out, and move on.
  • If you need to cry or scream, do it. The sooner you let go of those emotions, the closer you will be to accepting your diagnosis. You can also try talking with a trusted friend or family member or writing about your emotions.
Realize your diagnosis does not define you. You are not the bipolar disorder. Bipolar disorder is only a brain imbalance. You are you. You did not cause the bipolar, it is not your fault, and you are not a bad person. Bipolar disorder is just something you have to live with, like diabetes, asthma, thyroid issues, or arthritis.[6] You have probably had the disorder since birth and inherited it from a family member.
  • Bipolar disorder is just one aspect of your life. If you put it into perspective, that it is one piece just like your favorite color, your favorite food, your favorite activities, and your career, it feels less overwhelming.
Be patient. For some people, acceptance of their bipolar diagnosis may take years. Some people deny that they have bipolar at all, while others see improvements and stop accepting that they have it. Be patient as your work towards acceptance and as you and your treatment team find what works best for you. Remind yourself that though you have this mental illness, acknowledge and treatment is the way to help you stay healthy.[7]
  • Often a diagnosis of bipolar II is more difficult to accept than bipolar I because the symptoms are milder.
Accept that your loved one is bipolar. It can be difficult to hear that your loved one has bipolar disorder. You may think that everything will change, including your relationship with them. However, remember that your loved one is still the same person they always have been.
  • Your loved one now is able to get treatment for their symptoms, manage their disorder, and live a fuller life.
Learn about bipolar disorder. One of the first things you should do after you get diagnosed with bipolar is to learn as much about bipolar as you can. This includes the symptoms, especially the symptoms of a manic episode. You should also learn about treatment options so you can make an informed decision about how to treat the disorder.
  • You may have misconceptions about bipolar because of your exposure to incorrect information in the past. Start researching bipolar as if you have never heard of the condition before.
  • Ask your doctor for resources. You can also find books on the subject, or look at reputable websites online. The Depression and Bipolar Support Alliance and National Alliance on Mental Illness are good resources to start with.
Get a second opinion. If you are unsure about your bipolar diagnosis, get a second opinion. Make an appointment to see a different psychiatrist, or search for an expert in bipolar disorders. Getting a second opinion never hurts, especially since mental illnesses can be difficult to diagnose.
  • If you have only seen your general physician but not a mental health expert, go see a psychiatrist, psychologist, therapist, or other mental health professional before you start treatment.
Seek support. Learning to accept your bipolar diagnosis and getting treatment may be difficult. You shouldn’t try to do it alone. Reach out to trusted family and friends for help. Tell them about your diagnosis, along with your fears or concerns. Ask them to be there for you if you need them.
  • Be aware that some people's opinions of you might change due to their lack of knowledge about the condition. This type of reaction would be entirely unwarranted. However, you might consider this as you are deciding who to tell.[8]
Connect with others who are bipolar. Millions of people around the world have bipolar disorder or other mood disorders. You may want to reach out and talk to others who are dealing with bipolar. These people are going through the same things you are, so they can help provide support and understand what you are feeling.
  • You may consider going to a bipolar disorder support group. These meetings will give you a safe space to talk about your feelings, ask questions, and discuss struggles and successes with others. You may talk to them about how they learned to accept the diagnosis. You may be able to find a support group online, such as by checking the NAMI website.[9]
  • Reach out online to others with bipolar. Many bipolar organizations have online communities where you can talk to people from around the world.
Research with your loved one. If your loved one has bipolar, do your own research. This can help you understand the symptoms, treatment, and prognosis for your loved one. Visit support groups with them, offer to go to the doctor, or talk to your loved one about their condition.
  • It may be helpful for you to learn about bipolar symptoms treatment. Think about what symptoms your loved one has demonstrated before. Learn how treatment will help those symptoms and give your loved one a more balanced life.
Remind yourself why treatment is important. Deciding to get treatment may feel like giving up or admitting defeat. That is an unhealthy way of thinking about your treatment. Bipolar treatment is very effective and can make your life better. Untreated bipolar is dangerous and can lead to destructive behavior.[10]
  • Be honest with yourself about your bipolar, your symptoms, and your actions. You may be productive in manic phases, but make a list of the negatives. Have you had relationship problems? Participated in unsafe or risky behaviors? Gotten into debt? Left untreated, bipolar can have a negative effect on your life.
Commit to treatment. One way to fully accept your diagnosis is to commit yourself to following your treatment. This means you go to your doctor’s appointments, you take your medication, and you make the appropriate lifestyle changes.[11] It is important to continue your treatment even if you start to feel better.
  • Only going halfway with your treatment is telling yourself you don’t need help because there’s nothing wrong with you.
Choose a bipolar specialist. When you are searching for a doctor to treat your bipolar, you should find one who specializes in bipolar disorder. Not all psychiatrists, psychologists, and therapists have experience treating the same thing. When you go to the doctor, ask them about their experience treating bipolar disorder.[12]
  • When you are searching for psychiatrists online or through your insurance company, you can usually find a list of the psychiatrist’s specializations in the info section. If you are unsure, contact the psychiatrist’s office to find out.
  • Ask your general practitioner for a referral for a good clinic.
  • You may have a treatment team that includes a doctor or psychiatrist who handles your medication and a therapist, psychologist, or licensed social worker who oversees your therapy.
Take medication. Treatment for bipolar generally combines medication with therapy. Not everyone responds to medication the same way, so you may try a few different types of medications before choosing the right one for you. Discuss your medication options with your doctor.[13]
  • The medications prescribed for bipolar disorder are mood stabilizers, atypical antipsychotics, and antidepressants.
  • The aim of medication is to stabilize your moods.[14]
Go to therapy. Psychotherapy is a common treatment for bipolar disorder. Often, you will receive cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT). In cognitive behavioral therapy, you work on replacing negative thought patterns with healthier ones. For bipolar, you and your therapist work on identifying and avoiding triggers, problem solving skills, and managing your symptoms.[15]
  • Another common therapy for bipolar is interpersonal and social rhythm therapy. Interpersonal therapy works on helping you improve your relationships. Improving relationships can help reduce stress, which is a big trigger for bipolar. Social rhythm therapy works on getting your daily routine normalized by helping you adopt better sleeping, eating, and exercising schedules.
Manage your symptoms. Certain lifestyle changes can help you manage your bipolar disorder. You should get on a regular sleep schedule. Getting enough rest helps keep your mood level. Regular exercising also helps with your symptoms. Exercise is a natural mood booster and can help you feel better.[16]
  • Work on stress relieving techniques. This may include yoga, Tai Chi, exercise, meditation, or deep breathing exercises.
  • Refrain from using drugs or alcohol. Both of these things can exacerbate mood swings and trigger relapses.
